The LFI indicator methodology was first applied in the North Sea (Greenstreet et al., 2011) and has subsequently been adapted to expand the indicator to the Celtic Seas (Shephard et al., 2011), Bay of Biscay and Iberian Coast (Modica et al., 2014) and Wider Atlantic (Mindel et al., 2018). The Large Fish Index (LFI) was developed to respond to fishing pressure on the proportion of large fish in demersal fish communities (species living on or near the seafloor) (Rochet et al., 2010). The Large Fish Index (LFI) was developed to respond to fishing pressure on the proportion of large fish in demersal fish communities (species living on or near the seafloor) (Rochet et al., 2010). The LFI indicator methodology was first applied in the North Sea (Greenstreet et al., 2011) and has subsequently been adapted to expand the indicator to the Celtic Seas (Shephard et al., 2011), Bay of Biscay and Iberian Coast (Modica et al., 2014) and Wider Atlantic (Mindel et al., 2018). u_shaped_ranking.context_window: For indicator assessment purposes, this single survey was split into its two regional components. Standard data collected on these surveys comprise numbers of each species of fish sampled in each trawl sample, measured to defined length categories (i.e., 1 cm below, so a fish with a recorded length of 14 cm would be between 14,00 cm and 14,99 cm in length).

Our vision is a clean, healthy and biologically diverse North-East Atlantic Ocean, which is productive, used sustainably and resilient to climate change and ocean acidification.
